College of Chemical Engineering Qingdao University of Science & Technology Qingdao 266042 PR China A facile wet-chemical method was utilized to graft the Pd x Ag1- x alloy nanoparticles on the Co@NC composites derived from ZIF-67 by carbonization at different temperatures. The characterization results verified that the carbonization temperature exhibits a marked influence on the physical properties of the Co@NC composites. The surface area increased with temperature, ensuring the high dispersion of the PdAg alloy nanoparticles on the surface of the Co@NC composites. The performance evaluation of the dehydrogenation reaction of formic acid showed that the PdAg alloy nanoparticles deposited on Co@NC obtained at a carbonization temperature of 900 °C exhibited the highest activity. The catalytic performance of PdAg/Co@NC catalysts towards H2 generation was strongly related to the composition of the PdAg alloy and followed the trend of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC > Pd1Ag1/Co@NC > Pd9Ag1/Co@NC > Pd/Co@NC > Pd1Ag2/Co@NC. The residual metallic Co in the carbon matrix is somewhat beneficial to improving the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Formic acid Dehydrogenation Pd-based alloy ZIF-67 Co@NC composite Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen derived from renewable resources is generally viewed as a promising clean energy carrier and one of the ultimate energy carriers to connect distributed power generation grids with various energy users in the future [1,2]. During past decades, liquid organic hydrogen carriers have captured widespread attention as potential candidates for reversible hydrogen storage and release. As a product of biomass processing, formic acid (HCOOH, FA) has been regarded as an excellent hydrogen storage medium for its nontoxicity, convenient transportation, high stability, abundance in nature, and high hydrogen content (4.4wt% or 53 gL−1) [3–5]. FA can release H2 under mild conditions through selective dehydrogenation (HCOOH → H2 + CO2). The only by-product of the reaction, CO2, can be recycled to FA via the reversible hydrogenation reaction, realizing a carbon-neutral cycle in principle [6]. However, FA dehydration should be avoided as far as possible because the by-product CO can poison fuel cell catalysts, restricting its most potential application in hydrogen supply for fuel cells. Thus, searching for catalysts with excellent activity and stability is significance for FA-based hydrogen production systems. A series of heterogeneous catalysts with better performance toward FA dehydrogenation has been designed and progressed [7]. Among these catalysts, palladium-based catalysts offer superior activity [8,9]. Alloying with a secondary metal, such as Ag [10,11], Au [12,13], Ir [14,15], Cu [16], Ni [17], and Co [18,19], is an effective strategy to tune the electronic properties and adsorption behaviors of Pd catalysts, leading to improved activity and anti-CO poisoning ability. For this purpose, bi-metallic PdAg nanoparticles (NPs) have attracted significant attention because alloying Pd with Ag resulted in electron-rich Pd sites, which favors FA dehydrogenation reaction [20,21]. In addition, considerable efforts have been devoted to anchoring Pd-based NPs on various supports for tuning the particle sizes and inhibiting their significant aggregations [22,23]. MOFs have attracted tremendous attention due to their flexible structures that can be tuned by varying the types and proportions of the metal cation and linkers [24,25]. Importantly, pyrolysis of MOF materials can obtain many MOF-derived nanomaterials, rendering it attractive in engineering both metallic and non-metallic catalysts with MOF as precursors [26,27]. Duan et al. fabricated Pd NPs anchored on MOF-derived porous carbon with N/Cr2O3 co-doping, which showed a turnover frequency (TOF) of 11,241 h−1 at 60 °C [28]. Zhang et al. used MOF-derived hierarchical carbons with abundant Fe-N-C sites to anchor ultrafine Pd NPs [29]. As far as we know, there are few studies on using ZIF-derived composites to immobilize PdAg NPs for the catalytic dehydrogenation of FA. Herein, Co@NC composite was prepared by carbonization of ZIF-67 and then served as the carrier to immobilize PdAg alloy NPs. A series of PdAg/Co@NC were obtained by changing the carbonization temperature and the molar ratio of Pd to Ag. The as-prepared Pd2Ag1/Co@NC shows good catalytic performance for the CO-free H2 generation from FA, yielding a high initial turnover frequency value of 294.4 h−1 at 30 °C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Palladium chloride (>59.5%), sodium chloride (>99.5%), silver nitrate (>99.5%), cobalt nitrate (>98.5%), sodium carbonate (>99.8%), sodium borohydride (>97%), formic acid (>98.5%, Maclin), sodium citrate (>99%, Maclin), and 2-methylimidazole (Aladdin) were used as obtained. 2.2 Synthesis of ZIF-67 and Co@NC composites The rhombic dodecahedron ZIF-67 crystals were synthesized according to a simple method described in a previous report [30]. Typically, 2.91 g Co(NO3)2∙6H2O and 3.52 g 2-methylimidazole were dispersed in 30 mL methanol, respectively. Then, the solution of 2-methylimidazole was added slowly to the cobalt nitrate solution and stirred at 25 °C for 12 h. The formed ZIF-67 microcrystals were collected by centrifugation, washed several times with methanol, and finally dried at 70 °C for 12 h. The Co@NC support was prepared by carbonizing ZIF-67 under an N2 atmosphere at high temperatures (700–900 °C). The original ZIF-67 powder was first put in a tubular furnace and then heated to the desired temperature at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. After maintaining for 2 h, the furnace was cooled to room temperature naturally. The composites obtained at different temperatures were labeled as Co@NC-X, X stands for the pyrolysis temperature. 2.3 Preparation of PdAg/Co@NC catalysts PdAg alloy NPs supported on the Co@NC composites were synthesized via a wetting chemistry reduction method. A certain amount of PdCl2 and NaCl were dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water to prepare a Na2PdCl4 solution. Typically, to synthesize Pd9Ag1/Co@NC, 50 mg Co@NC-X carrier and 30 mg sodium citrate stabilizer were added to 5 mL deionized water and sonicated for 30 min to form a suspension. Then, the aqueous solution containing Na2PdCl4 (0.11 M, 0.4 mL) and AgNO3 (0.1 M, 0.05 mL) was added to the suspension of Co@NC-X. After stirring for 60 min, 5 mL of freshly configured reducing agent (38 mg NaBH4 dissolved in 0.02 M Na2CO3) was slowly added and stirred for 0.5 h. Fig. 1 schematically illustrates the procedure used herein to prepare PdAg/Co@NC. For comparison, Pd/Co@NC, Ag/Co@NC, and PdAg/Co@NC (Pd9Ag1, Pd2Ag1, Pd1Ag1, and Pd1Ag2) were prepared by controlling the proportions of Pd and Ag in the precursor solution. All catalysts have a nominal metal loading of 9.7 wt%. 2.4 Catalyst characterizations The morphologies and compositions of the samples were characterized with JEM-F2000 transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (INCA Sight X, Oxford). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was obtained with a JEM-2100Plus instrument operating at 200 kV. Powder X-ray diffraction was conducted with a D/max-2500/PC X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Corporation, Japan) using Cu Kα at 40 kV and 159 mA. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, AXIS SUPRA, UK) with AlKα radiation was used to analyze the surface compositions. The N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP2460–2 instrument. 2.5 Catalyst evaluation The details of experiments on formic acid dehydrogenation and evaluations of the catalytic activity can be found in our previous study [21]. The molar ratio of metal to FA (n metal/n FA) was kept at 0.01. Turnover frequency (TOF) is calculated by the ratio of the molar amount of formic acid consumed per unit time to the molar amount of metal. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations XRD patterns Pd/Co@NC, Ag/Co@NC, and Pd2Ag1/Co@NC prepared with Co@NC-900 as the support are shown in Fig. 2 . For the Co@NC composite, the broad peak at about 26° signified the (002) plane of graphite-type carbon, which was formed from carbonization of 2-methylimidazole. The intense peaks that appeared at 44.2, 51.6, and 76.0° are respectively assigned to (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of face-centered cubic cobalt (JCPDS No.15–0806), suggesting the reduction of Co2+ during the pyrolysis process [31]. The Pd/Co@NC, Ag/Co@NC, and Pd2Ag1/Co@NC show weak diffraction peaks of noble metal because of their marked lower contents than that of metallic Co. In the Ag/Co@NC sample, the characteristic peaks were located at 38.1, 64.4, and 77.5°, corresponding to the crystalline (111), (200), and (311) facets of metallic Ag (JCPDS No. 65–2871), respectively. It should be noted that the diffraction peak of the (220) facet of metallic Ag (44.3°) coincides with that of the (111) facet of metallic Co (44.2°). In the Pd/Co@NC sample, two weak peaks of metallic Pd appear at 40.1 and 46.7°, ascribed to (111) and (200) facets (JCPDS No. 89–4897), respectively. By comparison, Pd2Ag1/Co@NC shows a broad peak at 38.8°, located between those of Pd and Ag, indicating the formation of PdAg alloy [32]. Moreover, a weak peak appears at 65.1°, which is higher than 64.4° for Ag (200), further confirming the formation of PdAg alloy. Fig. 3 presents the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distributions of the Co@NC composites obtained by carbonizing ZIF-67 at different temperatures and the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalysts. All the Co@NC composites display combined I and IV types isotherms, i.e., the most N2 adsorption occurred at a relative pressure (P/P0) below 0.05, and an H4 hysteresis loop appeared in the P/P0 range of 0.4–1.0 (Fig. 3a). The above characteristics indicate the coexistence of micropores and mesopores [33]. The Co@NC-700 composite shows a bi-modal pore size distribution, while Co@NC-800 and Co@NC-900 display much narrow pore size distributions (inset of Fig. 3a). As listed in Table 1 , the BET surface areas of the Co@NC composites increase with calcination temperature. The increase of specific surface area with pyrolysis temperature is consistent with literate relating to the preparation of ZIF-67@melamine-derived carbon [34]. The above results might be due to the migration of tiny Co NPs at a higher carbonization temperature, producing nano-scale pores in the carbon-based composite [35]. As expected, the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalysts kept the same physical structure as the Co@NC composites because the PdAg alloy NPs were post-synthesized (Fig. 3b). As shown in Table 1, the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalysts have a little higher surface area and broader pore size distribution than their corresponding Co@NC composites, possibly attributed to the formation of secondary pores by agglomeration of PdAg alloy NPs. Fig. 4 depicts the SEM and TEM images of the pristine ZIF-67 and Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900. As shown in Fig. 4a, the ZIF-67 exhibits a well-dispersed dodecahedron structure with good crystallinity and a size of less than 2 μm. In comparison, the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalyst has a mixed morphology, with some retaining similar size and polyhedron features to ZIF-67 and others transforming into non-regular porous carbon materials as the result of the collapse of the skeleton structure (Fig. 4b). As shown in the EDS spectrum (Fig. 5 a), the ratio of Pd to Ag is 4.3:2.9, close to that of two metal precursors. The element mapping image of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC indicates that Pd, Ag, and Co are homogeneously distributed over the entire carbon architecture (Fig. 5b). The detailed nano-structures of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC were further characterized by TEM and HRTEM (Fig. 6 ). The morphological feature of ZIF-67 was retained even calcined at temperature as high as 900 °C. As shown from a representative high-resolution TEM image of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-700 in Fig. 6b, two` main phases of the dispersed cobalt-relating NPs are metallic Co and Co3O4, signifying by the lattice fringes with spacing distances of 0.205 nm for Co (111) and 0.245 nm for Co3O4 (311), respectively [36,37]. One nanocrystal with a lattice fringe spacing of 0.231 nm falls between 0.224 nm of the Pd (111) crystal plane and 0.238 nm of the Ag (111) crystal plane, suggesting a (111) crystal plane of the PdAg alloy structure. In addition, the distinct lattice fringe with a spacing distance of 0.198 nm corresponds to the (200) crystal plane of AgPd alloy [38]. Importantly, pure Pd or Ag planes were hardly identified from the HRTEM images, confirming that both Pd and Ag almost totally formed alloys. Compared with Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-800, the (200) crystal plane of CoO with a spacing distance of 0.213 nm can be observed (Fig. 6d). As to Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900, the metallic NPs became much more dispersed (Fig. 6e). Notably, no Co3O4 or CoO crystal planes apart from metallic Co NPs are observed (Fig. 6f). Most PdAg alloy NPs have intimate contact with metallic Co NPs. In addition, some PdAg alloy defects can be found. These results suggested that the calcination temperature could influence the physical structure of Co@NC and the crystalline phase of Co-related species, and the latter might further affect the dispersion and microenvironment of PdAg alloy NPs. The full survey XPS spectrum of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC exhibits the presence of C, O, N, Co, Pd, and Ag elements (Fig. 7 a). As shown in Fig. 7b and 7c, the spin-orbit separations of Pd 3d and Ag 3d are 5.29 and 6.00 eV, respectively, identifying the nature of metallic Pd and Ag [39]. As shown in Fig. 7b, the Pd 3d3/2 and Pd 3d1/2 peaks can be deconvolved into two couples, ascribed to metallic Pd0 and Pd2+ species, respectively [40]. The presence of Pd2+ may be caused by the surface oxidation of surface Pd crystals [41]. A negative shift of about 0.1 eV occurred in the binding energy of Pd 3d after the introduction of Ag, signifying that some electrons were moved from Ag to Pd [42]. Based on the deconvoluted Co 2p1/2 curves, three peaks at around 779.2, 781.0, and 783.1 eV were assigned to surface Co0, Co3+, and Co2+, respectively (Fig. 7d), which is inconsistent with HRTEM observations. 3.2 Catalytic decomposition of FA The influence of carbonization temperature on the catalytic performances of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalysts was investigated toward FA dehydrogenation at 30 °C with the participation of SF. As shown in Fig. 8 a, b, the catalytic performance of the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalysts is highly dependent on the carbonization temperature, with the Pd2Ag1 alloy NPs anchored on the Co@NC-900 having much higher activity than these supported on Co@NC-800 and Co@NC-700, corresponding to TOF of 294.4, 168.9, and 72.4 h−1, respectively. It was confirmed that the graphitization degree of ZIF-67-derived carbon increases with carbonization temperature [43]. Deng et al. indicated that the higher degree of graphitization is favorable for the electron transfer between the PdCo NPs, thus for hydrogen evolution from formic acid [44]. Therefore, the higher degree of graphitization, relatively larger surface area, and intimate contact between metallic Co and PdAg alloy NPs might contribute to the better performance of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900. The catalytic properties of bi-metallic alloy are strongly dependent on its composition. Fig. 8c shows the plots of the volume of evolved gas versus time for FA dehydrogenation catalyzed by the PdAg/Co@NC catalysts with different alloy compositions. As shown, the mono-metallic Ag catalyst provided almost no activity towards the dehydrogenation of FA, signifying that Pd plays a decisive role in the catalytic process. The catalytic activity of Pd/Co@NC was improved by alloying Ag and increased accordingly with the composition of Pd except for Pd1Ag2/Co@NC. The low activity of the Pd1Ag2/Co@NC catalyst is because of the relatively low content of Pd compared with that of Ag, which led to the occupation of the catalyst surface by more inactive Ag sites [45]. The Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalyst displays the highest gas generation rate, corresponding to TOF of 294.4 h−1 (Fig. 8d), comparable with the previously reported catalysts (Table 2 ). In contrast, the catalytic ability of Pd9Ag1/Co@NC with the highest Pd content decreased, reflecting the undesirable alloy composition. It is accepted that the intrinsic electronic properties of the metallic NPs are closely related to their activity toward formic acid decomposition [52,53]. Therefore, the high activity of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC is most possibly ascribed to its appropriate surface electronic state, which provides a moderate binding to formate. It merits noting that the reported compositions of PdAg alloy showing the highest activity are somewhat different because the alloy nanostructure, its interaction with the support, and the physiochemical properties of the carriers can influence the catalytic performance. The effects of the SF/FA molar ratio on the volume of evolved gas versus the reaction time were investigated. In the case of pure FA only, only 80 mL gas was generated, while no gas was observed in the case of pure SF (Fig. 8e), indicating that the gas generated by SF hydrolysis can be neglected. However, the dehydrogenation rate gradually increased with SF/FA molar ratio. The presence of SF can increase the solubility of HCOO– ion in the solution, which is conducive to the contact between formic acid and the active centers [54,55]. The increase of the molar ratio of FA/SF from 0.3 to 1.0 led to an increasing in TOF from 106.2 to 294.4 h−1 (Fig. 8f). A continued increase of the ratio to 1.5:1.0 induced a marked reduction in the dehydrogenation performance of the catalyst. Recent study about formic acid dehydrogenation indicated that although there is a small interaction between Co and Pd, its effect on the catalyst performance can be neglected [56]. Other comparative experiments were conducted to elucidate the possible role of the retained metallic Co in strengthening the activity and stability of the Pd2Ag1 alloy catalyst. The Co@NC was treated with 1 M H2SO4 solution for Co removal, stirred vigorously at room temperature for 72 h, washed with deionized water three times, and dried in an oven at 70 °C for 12 h to obtain Co-etched NC. As shown in Fig. 9 a, Co@NC and Co-free NC have almost no activity toward the dehydrogenation of formic acid. Interestingly, Pd2Ag1/Co@NC exhibited somewhat higher activity than Pd2Ag1/NC, implying the synergistic role of the metallic Co derived from the carbonization of ZIF-67. As the HRTEM images indicated, part of the metallic Co NPs has intimate contact with PdAg alloy NPs, which can influence the electronic properties of PdAg alloy. Additionally, a speculation on the synergistic effect of Co is the hydrogen spillover from the PdAg alloy to metallic Co [57]. Other experiments were conducted by introducing the same amount of FA into the system at the first reaction time of 14 min (50% conversion) (Fig. 9b). It can be found that the reaction rate of the make-up section was close to the initial reaction rate in the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC sample. In contrast, the reaction rate of the make-up section showed a much reduction in the Pd2Ag1/NC sample. It is demonstrated that the presence of the restricted Co ensures the high stability of the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC catalyst. However, future research is still required to help elucidate the exact role of the retained metallic Co in a carbon matrix. The FA dehydrogenation at different temperatures (293, 303, 313, and 323 K) over Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900 was also studied. As depicted in Fig. 9c, a rapid increase in activity with temperature can be observed. The rate constant (k) was determined by the linear slope of the dehydrogenation plots. From the Arrhenius plot ln k vs. 1/T (Fig. 9d), the activation energy of the Pd2Ag1/Co@CN catalyst was estimated to be 32.1 kJ/mol. The repeated use test of the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900 catalyst for FA dehydrogenation at 303 K is shown in Fig. 10 . The hydrogen production rate of the catalyst was well maintained during three cycle tests, indicating good stability of the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900 catalyst. The slight increase in reaction time after three cycles was possibly due to the catalyst loss during the recycling process. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have demonstrated the preparation of a novel PdAg/Co@NC catalyst by anchoring PdAg alloy NPs on ZIF-67-derived Co@NC composite. The catalytic performance of PdAg/Co@NC is highly dependent on the PdAg alloy composition and Co@NC structure, with the Pd2Ag1/Co@NC-900 exhibiting high activity and stability for the dehydrogenation of FA to produce hydrogen with the assistance of SF, yielding an initial TOF of 294.4 h−1 and apparent activation energy of 32.1 kJ mol−1 under FA/SF molar ration of 1.0:1.0 at 30 °C. Characterizations proved that the calcination temperature significantly affects the physical structure of the Co@NC composites and the phase structure of Co-related species. It can be inferred that the retained metallic Co in the carbon matrix exhibits a synergistic effect on strengthening the activity and stability of the Pd2Ag1 alloy catalyst by an interaction. Future research is still required to help elucidate the synergistic mechanism. CRediT authorship contribution statement Zhongcheng Zhao: Visualization, Investigation, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: A facile wet-chemical method was utilized to graft the Pd x Ag1- x alloy nanoparticles on the Co@NC composites derived from ZIF-67 by carbonization at different temperatures. The characterization results verified that the carbonization temperature exhibits a marked influence on the physical properties of the Co@NC composites. The surface area increased with temperature, ensuring the high dispersion of the PdAg alloy nanoparticles on the surface of the Co@NC composites. The performance evaluation of the dehydrogenation reaction of formic acid showed that the PdAg alloy nanoparticles deposited on Co@NC obtained at a carbonization temperature of 900 °C exhibited the highest activity. The catalytic performance of PdAg/Co@NC catalysts towards H2 generation was strongly related to the composition of the PdAg alloy and followed the trend of Pd2Ag1/Co@NC > Pd1Ag1/Co@NC > Pd9Ag1/Co@NC > Pd/Co@NC > Pd1Ag2/Co@NC. The residual metallic Co in the carbon matrix is somewhat beneficial to improving the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Anchoring PdAg nanoparticles on ZIF-67-derived Co@NC composite as a catalyst for efficient hydrogen evolution from formic acid
